element_texts.text: Completed

Top of page is written 'Emma's letter, 2 days after Great fire' and crossed out


                                                                                     Chicago, October 11th  1871

Darling Mother - 

                       I beg of you not to be alarmed, we are

safe, sound and I can almost say happy - as happy 
as we could possibly be under the circumstances 
with so much suffering all around us.  Our home on
Huron Street is in ruins but we have as comfortable 
a one as one could wish at George Broomell's with the 
heartiest kind of a welcome.
Although Mr. H's losses will be heavy, still it is not
half as bad as we had reason to expect.  He had
$75,000 dash with 2 zeros above the dash to indicate zero cents in Securities 'in Securities' inserted by caret deposited in one place and the first rumor
was that it would be a perfect loss, and that the 'other' written but crossed off
banks where he had made deposits were afraid their
vaults would be worthless, but the reports yesterday 
were very encouraging 'for nearly all' written but crossed off and he does
not know but all 'all' is underlined of those in which he is interested
are in good condition.  The safe belonging to him in 
his office will be taken from the ruins where it is
buried today, still he is not much concerned about that
for he went down town Sunday night soon after the
fire began and took the most valuable papers out
and has them here, so he is not at all distressed about 
it, so you see he may be thought comparatively rich yet
Completed

2.

though at first we did not know but what we were 
penniless with thousands of others.
Oh Mother, I am so glad you were not here, for such
a "reign of terror" was never known.  We were 
awakened Sunday night just before twelve by Frankie.
She came running down 'stairs' is written but crossed out to our room and wanted
me to go up and see the fire from her room.  There was
light enough to read by there.  We supposed it was
burning somewhere near the fire of the night before
(which you heard burned over 'over' inserted by caret twenty acres) and thought
it too far away to have the least fear for our safety.
At last the bells began to ring furiously from all parts
of the city, tugs screamed, and all the propeller whistles
were blowing at once, so Chalkley thought something 
terrible was happening so dressed and went down town 
As soon as he went away we began to pack some of
the valuables laughing at ourselves while doing it,
but at last got so much alarmed that we worked 
with a will.  The sparks and large pieces of burning 
wood had been flying all around the house for an
hour and a half and at quarter past two came in a 
perfect shower and at half past a policeman came
and told us to hurry for our lives.  Chalkley was 
not home and we were nearly distracted, but he
Completed

3.

came in about ten minutes.  Must stop short off here
for Chalkley wants to mail this and can't wait a minute.
Will write this afternoon again and tell you of our escape.

                                               Emma.


Dear Mother,

        I broke my letter off very abruptly this morning 

and although it hardly seemed a subject for levity
we could not help laughing when I told Mrs. B. and Frank 
of its abrupt termination at such a critical moment.
Mrs. B. said I should have said "to be continued next 
month 'month' underlined a la New York Ledger".
But to resume, Mr. H. had been watching the fire on
the South Side and did not dream that his office was 
in danger until he saw the Court House in a mass
of flame, (it ran like lightning over the building.)
He then rushed to his office for his safe.  Of course it
was dark and he had a great deal of difficulty
in opening it with the combination lock, but
succeeded in getting the most valuable papers
and by the time he got down from the office State St.
bridge was burning.  The Sherman House a mass of flame,
and everything near it, and Wright's Livery stable on fire
on the North Side.  His only chance then for the
Completed

4.

North Side was over Rush Street bridge.  He ran with all
his might and crossed just in time, the flames following
close behind.  He had not got further than Michigan Street
before he saw the water works afire.  Although the wind
blew the burning embers a little east of 336, still he
did not know but what we were already on fire, but when
he got to the house told us not 'not' inserted by caret to hurry too much but save 
all we could carry in our arms.  Although the house
was in such danger and all around us had gone 
we stayed long enough to take the most valuable clothing
out of the trunks where we had packed them (we had worked
hard and got them down into the hall) and put them 
into Lammie's baby carriage.  I carried Lammie in my
arms and Frank and Mary came with numerous bundles
and then we went out of our beautiful home with the 
flames to take our part in the horrible tragedy.
If we had not had the stoutest hearts we should
have sank right there, but we had worked desperately 
from the first (Frank was a host in herself).
Mary, (the servant) '(the servant)' inserted by caret as soon as the policeman told us to run
for our lives began to cry and wring her hands, but 
I told her to stop crying in an instant and work,
if she wanted to save anything.  She looked at me
a moment in horror, and then fell to work with a will.
Completed

5.

Hundreds of dollars would not have hired a team then, 
so we went out as I told you before in the midst of a 
shower of sparks and burning embers flying faster
and thicker than the heaviest snow storm you ever 
saw, with the water works just coming down with
a crash, and all ways cut off by fire except to hurry
straight north.  It is the greatest wonder we were
not burned alive from the falling fire, but managed 
to get over to Dearborn Street where we met Mr. Colyer
who told us to go up to the church and go into his study, but
be careful that no one else got in till he came back.
We were very glad of the word 'course' is written and then scratched out some such refuge, for we
were ready to drop the word 'drop' was inserted by caret from our heavy loads (without them
walking was almost an impossibility on account
of the terrific wind) but the fire gained on us so
fast that I was afraid to stop anywhere inside the 
city limits (in one place four blocks burned
in twenty minutes) and looking back all we could
see was a solid mass of flame roaring and crackling
behind us, with a terrified and panic stricken 
crowd flying before it.  The wind was changing at
that time, so Chalkley thought the church might not
be in immediate danger, so went in.  It was 
three o'clock in the morning when we left the house, and
Completed

6.

at about five Mr. Colyer came in and said "where is your
husband, Mrs. Hambleton?"  I told him he was outside 
the church and he said "We are no longer safe here.
I have just seen the last of my home, and now my
church must go."  The great man sobbed like a babe.
Mrs. Colyer seemed completely stupefied.  So again 
we were driven out and had gone as far as Clark St.
on Lasalle and were sitting on a church step to
rest when Lee Fogg dashed past with a horse and
buggy.  George Gilbert was with him.  They espied
us and came right back, and Lee took Lammie in
his arms in an instant and took him to the carriage 
and then came for me.  We were all he could carry
so had to have Frank, Mr. H and Mary to come on as
best they could.  We were all delighted that Lammie 
could be in a place of safety.  Lee took us to his home
beyond Lincoln Park and in about an hour Frankie and
Mr. H. came, having walked all the way - and loaded too.
We were there about two miles from where the fire 
was raging, so felt safe for a short time.  Mr. H. started
out right away to find a conveyance to take us to the 
West Side, and could not find a thing until he had
walked all the way to West Lake St.  He got back to
Mr. Fogg's just as we were going into the streets for
Completed

7.

the third time, for Mr. Fogg had told us we must go 
immediately with them out to his daughters at Lake 
View, a mile and a half.  His carriage and Mrs. 
Howe's had been for the last two hours drawing their
goods into the country, and Mrs. Fogg and a whole
house full the word 'of' is written and then crossed off who had flocked there for protection 
with us were going to walk that distance (and
of course all we had saved would have been left
behind).  When Mr. H drove up with the coach it 
was a welcome sight, I assure you.  He piled
us all in and took us out of danger and then
left Frank at one side of the road to carry the ladies
to Lake View.  The sand was so deep the horses could
not draw us all and we had made up our minds
to go on the West Side.  So waited until the coach 
came back and then rode over to George Broomell's.
I think we were two hours and a half getting there,
the roads were so crowded with flying people.
After we arrived we did not dare unpack our
goods for fear of the winds changing and the
West Side burning up.  We were relieved from our
anxiety at midnight by a shower of rain, and 
could sleep then for the first time in more than 
fifty hours.  George Ramsey's house was on fire
Completed

8.

where we left ours, and in the streets were the families
of the richest men in Chicago running, some lost,
and many sitting right on the pavement for a
moment's breaths, dressed in velvets silk the word 'silk' inserted by caret and jewels they
were trying to save.  The fire was a wonderful 
leveler, if I may use that expression.  Life was 
the only question then.
We are not entirely safe yet, and will not be until
we have more rain, for of course there is no water
to use.  Mr. Broomell was mustered in as patrol Tuesday
evening and all the citizens are working day and
night to save what remains of the city.  Troops are
here from Omaha and have Gen. Sheridan for leader and are guarding faithfully the ruins and
dangerous parts of the city.  Placards are posted all
round the ruins announcing that any person 
attempting to steal will be killed instantly and 
without mercy.  That is the only thing that will 
protect property now, for there are so many convicts
out, as of course the Armory is burned and all other
places of confining desperados on the South Side.
All day Monday the Mayor sent orders all over the 
city that no fires were to be built in the houses under
any considerations, and no smoking of cigars
Completed

9.

Mother, we saved your cloak, black shawl, breakfast shawl 
and I am so glad that the best part of your clothing was
with you for it would have been impossible to have saved
but as small part of it had it been here.  Frankie 
saved her green suit and black suit, cloak and quite
a number of under clothes, so she will be quite comfortable 
Her furs too, she saved.
I saved a few of Lammie's clothes and almost all of
Mr. H's outside clothing and my more antique, black
silk, grenedine, brown silk, checked silk, satin and
velvet cloak, with nearly all my valuable laces
and embroideries, my winter outside garments,
and three shawls.  But our library was completely 
destroyed - not a volume saved (too heavy to carry of 
course) and all my beautiful silver gone the words 'beautiful', 'silver', and 'gone' and are underlined.  If we
could have carried a trunk could have saved it 
but that was out of the question.  Although it seems 
to you but little is left, still we did astonishingly
well everyone says that sees all we carried.  All your
bedding has gone with mine.  My splendid piano 
is a mass of shapeless wire.
Mother, if the friends will give you a home this winter, or until
we are organized again I will do something for them 
sometime.  I am sorry I cannot offer you a home
Completed

10.

but will promise to take good care of Frank and keep her
right with us and she shall not want for anything.
I went out yesterday and bought quite a number of things
for her.
Will write to 'to' inserted by caret Aunt Lizzie soon - can't write any more
at present.

                                     Emma
Completed

Mrs. Vera S. Wolfe
                                                      306 N. Cascade Avenue
                                                    Colorado Springs, Colo. 80902

Poppy Dear:

   What fun to get your letter, and unclear
are delighted, although not surprised that you
and Jack are doing the decor for another 

Symphony Ball-

  However dear Poppy, your very welcome

and gratifying request could not have come at
a worse time.  I just yesterday returned from
hospital, after rather long drawn-out major?
surgery (no details- what could be more boring)
and have to return very shortly for some
final patching up.  If there is time, could you
give me a few more details of exactly what
you could use.  Though I am a bit woozy
and the brain no doubt fuzzy, I would be
happy to do my best to send along something.
I am enclosing a few things that might 
amuse you but unclear be completely unclear the
unclear back? or what you had in mind-

   You asked about those parties at Lowe?-

they were always after the Thursday night 
concerts and I hope you were there when
unclear did his imitation of Yehudi? Wenuhia's?
Completed

first concerts (he also did that at unknown)
unknown was 14 years old when he made his
debut - in short pants and knee socks - So, as
you may recall, unknown rolled up his pants
legs, assumed the unknown 2 words pose
and played the "Flight of the Bumble Bee" - 

        We were always so happy to have

you with us and I will remember the time
you thanked my mother for offering you
a glass of unknown, but that you would
get your own.  Incidentally, that may have
unclearthe evening Horowitz had a unclear much
of the inocuous testing stuff and played
until 3:00 A.M.  Those Tiding on the 9th
often told me later they practically lay with
their ears on the floor, knowing who was
playing.

      Please give Mrs. Upham my best

greeting and tell her I tried to reach her
that year I was in Chicago but she was
still in Keene Valley (I believe that is the place)

        I hope to hear from you while

there is still time, provided you can tell me
a little more specifically what you would like
to have

        My greetings to Jack - best of luck

for another great Ball.

                                          Affectionaly Vera
Completed

1
  The first thing that pops into my

mind is that old chestnut (so often
gleefully, printed by the press) about
Stock taking golf lessons, in northern
Wisconsin the pro standing patiently
by while his pupil either sliced,
hooked or missed the ball completely.
Finally, at his wit's end, the pro
blurted out:  "the trouble with you,
Mister, you ain't got no rhythm."

   This one of course, is so old and has

gone the rounds so many times that 
it may even have been forgotten
long flourished line across middle of page

   I have always liked the stories about

my father's inability to dance - although
I often suspected it was more a
matter of unwillingness - At any rate
I know these two are true because
I was there -
Completed

2

At one party a very lovely lady finally
got Stock on the dance floor and what
followed can easily be pictured if
you have seen Yul Bryner in "Anna 
and the King of Siam"  Surely you
recall the delightful sequence when
Anna and the King take those first
steps in "Shall we Dance".  Father's
first attempts were exactly as inept and
his confusion as complete as the King's - 
that a simple "one, two, three" can also
be done by the feet.  Stock quickly
realized that this "silly shuffling around"
was getting him nowhere and with a
gracious bow and the promise that it
work better next time, he led the lady
back to the table.
Underlined flourish in the middle of the page

      One of the funniest episodes I

ever saw, and this also concerns dancing,
happened on board ship.  After dinner,
Stock had been repeatedly coaxed to
Completed

3

dance - It was a slightly stormy
evening, with the ship gently rolling
and pitching, just enough for father
to get that "you-asked-for-it" idea
and somehow I knew in a flash what
was coming.  Taking a lady by the
hand, he got into a most formal dance
position with her and simply stood at
the edge of the floor - no steps were
taken and at exactly the right moment
when the ship pitched forward, slid her
diagonally across the floor without
moving a foot, then stood there, just
waiting for the ship's next roll - 
Please try to picture it!  The other
dancers left the floor - partly in self 
defense because there wasn't room
enough but mostly in complete hilarity.
The best part of it was that Stock was
completely unself-conscious and the
lady's face a mask of utter
Completed

4

disbelief and helplessness - His timing
was perfect with each pitch of the
ship and what finally stopped him
was the tremendous applause and roars
of laughter - And I am sure he
appreciated that applause as much
as any he ever got on any concert
stage
Completed

5

This story is rather long, complicated, unknown
and technical, but anyone with a vivid imagination
like yours could certainly make the most of it
I cannot come anywhere near the date of
this concert but perhaps someone as senile? as Mrs.
Upham, had she been there, may have caught on
during the subtle, almost melodramatic moments of
this episode, hilarious and near disaster:
Naturally, it is always customary for a
soloist to rehearse with the Orchestra before a
performances - that is, with the exception of
pianist Josef Hofmann and Frederick Stock.  Their
long association together, his frequent appearances
with the Orchestra seemed to make a rehearsal
less mandatory - Even during the usual shop-talk
before the performance, the subject of the
Concerto for Piano, for some almost unbelievable
reason, never came up.  What makes it even more
fantastic is that Hofmann thought he was to 
play the Beethoven Concerto No. 2 in B flat,
while actually the Schumann A minor was on 
the program.

       And now for the hilarious but near disastrous

results of this incredible mix-up - Hofmann, 
seated at the piano, bowed to the conductor and
Orchestra, quite the natural and accepted procedure,
Completed

6

that is - once.  Stock raised his baton, nodded to the
soloist, who remained with hands on his knees, 
and nodded back.  These amenities were repeated - 
how please join in the obviously, growing tension -
The Orchestra grew restive and still nothing
happened.  Now, the Beethoven Concerto opens with 
the principal theme, Allegro con brio, with the
Orchestra - But the Schumann starts with a 
flourish of a few bars from the piano!

---So, here were Stock and Hofmann still

sparring and the oboist (who plays the first
phrase of the principal theme in the Schumann)
waiting in the most obvious misery for Hofmann
to begin - After an almost unbearable interval 
Stock finally realized what must have
happened and hissed:  "Hofmann, we're playing
the Schumann."  With a charming "Ah so"
Hofmann crashed into his 3-bar opening of
the concerto and it all ended with a brilliant
performance.

       Afterwards, in the dressing room there was

much back slapping between soloist and conductor
though one imagines that the uproarious laughter
accompanying it was mixed with a bit of 
panic-

      The conversation, translated from German:
Completed

7

Hofmann: "next time, rehearsal, yes."
Stock:  "next time??"
One wonders how much of this got about.
Naturally, members of the Orchestra playfully 
must have spread the story - and what about
the critics?  Stock's frantic hiss at Hofmann
had been completely inaudible - Only the 
actual facts remain - the rest of this mix-up
is still quite a mystery

   Wish I had a typewriter but hope you

can read the scrawl.
underline flourish in the middle of the page after the last sentence
Completed

3/14/27

                My dear Son

Your letter with the happy news 
came last evening and did
delight me indeed  If you
will give me a few days notice
I will be sure to meet you either
at Pasadena or Los Angeles
Yes, the well at the ranch was 
a dug well, but it was not quite
eighty feet deep, while the one
at the "Gabana there is an 's' above and between the 'n' and 'a' Soleded" is one
hundred and forty feet down
There is a law in this state that
Completed

after an excavation is over one hundred 
feet there shall be appliances
for plenty of fresh air, also that
there is a five hundred dollar state
fine for an employer who does
not have accident insurance for
his workmen.  Spencer disregarded
both of these laws, and has been in
great danger of the penalties being
exacted, but his wife and eight
children, besides his "no funds" two words underscored state
may let him out.  If Jones had
had any dependents, the Insurance
company, in which I was insured
might have had to pay from five
to ten thousand dollars, not a person three words underscored
Completed

has been found yet who knows anything
at all about him or his relatives,
most people think he was living under
an assumed name.  The man Kitch
who so miraculously escaped death after
over four hours in that poison pit, is
at work again, seemingly as good as new
but Titus still suffers from his heart which 
was so badly effected, when he went to 
the rescue of Jones and Kitch
How easily that could have been a triple underscore
tragedy.  The Lancaster Masons helped
bury Jones, as from his papers they found
he belonged to that order, but from what
state they could not find out.
He had one hundred and fifty dollars
deposited in the Lancaster Bank and I 
owed him twenty dollars, but cannot pay
it until I am given instructions.
Hoping that all will be in a normal
state by the time you arrive I am

         Yours devotedly
                         Mother

March fourteenth. [Emma Lander Hambleton]
Completed

10/13/32
Hambleton
My dear Son
Jonathan has gotten himself in a pretty tight box this time and if the woman died he will very surely hang. He was captured yesterday. For his last offense I have no sympathy for it evidently was premeditated murder two words underscored. I really hope they will put him out of the way, for the good of the neighborhood In the meantime I shall have to be busy and find someone to take his place In some ways he was a very useful man, but his uncontrollable temper, make him a
(vertical in the left margin starting at the bottom)
please let mand? see this clipping if you can
Completed

dangerous one to handle I told him once that is he did not mind his ways he would surely swing. I laughed when I said it is he might have finished me then and there. I talked so plainly to him sometimes that Mildred was afraid for me, but that was the only way to control such a man. I was probably in danger of sudden death many times the papers have not arrived yet, but I think those of the ranch will have to be taken to Bakersfield. Mr J[unclear] will tell me. Much love to my dear unclear
Mother
